title: Fix deducing git ignored state for files too, not only directories
body:
Fix #656 (I knew I had the idea for this PR from somewhere!!).

Follow-up of #841.

- The aggregation logic was only implemented for directories, since it doesn’t make sense for files. However, when I added the logic that a directory is considered ignored if a parent directory is, I forgot to implement it for files too.
- Added tests to check that a non-ignored parent directory of an ignored content isn’t flagged as ignored, and that the content of an ignored directory is flagged as ignored too.

This should be good this time!! Next time, I should probably use the draft PR feature when I know I need to add or fix stuff…

title: Fix --git deducing ignored state in unintuitive way
body:
Fix #840 

It makes sense to consider that a directory has the aggregated status of all the files under it.

The exception is that for the ignored status, it’s more useful and intuitive to consider that it applies to everything under it.

- A directory containing an ignored file is no longer considered ignored
- A file inside an ignored directory is now considered ignored

title: Fix month name not following locale when date is in current year
body:
Fix #833 

Since #509, the format used for the date of the current year was not taking locale into account.

It does now, with a simpler and shorter code, and a test.

title: Fix `EXA_GRID_ROWS` not working in some cases
body:
Fix #835

In #790, I introduced an [early return](https://github.com/ogham/exa/pull/790/files#diff-4b2bc2ee82b980f63ad43373e8899a9527b74ab163a5317e2b00d975fd16061aR178) that short-circuits [the `EXA_GRID_ROWS` logic](https://github.com/ogham/exa/pull/790/files#diff-4b2bc2ee82b980f63ad43373e8899a9527b74ab163a5317e2b00d975fd16061aR186), so in some cases (namely, when the grid can fit in one row), `EXA_GRID_ROWS` is ignored.

This PR fixes that and introduces xtests to avoid future regressions. I also changed a comment to make it clear where’s the logic to handle `EXA_GRID_ROWS`.

I’m still not sure if the header line should be counted as an output row; right now, there’s no specific logic for when the option is used, so it’s counted as such.

title: Use thousand separators again and fix alignement when it’s not ASCII
body:
Fix #657

- If the number has no prefix (Ki, Mi, etc.), use `format_int()` instead of `to_string()` to use thousand separator
- Use `DisplayWidth::from()` on strings instead of assuming ASCII.

I introduced a regression in #822: I used `format_float()` instead of `format_int()` in certain cases, but the first doesn’t include thousand separators in its representation, so it fixed the alignment issue but now the numbers aren’t displayed properly.

So, the initial bug was that when using `-b`, sometimes the size of a file is for example between 1000KiB and 1024KiB, so it’s under 1MiB and it’s the only case where thousands separator were used (since no thousand separator is used with `-B`). Size of numbers was computed by using stdlib `.len()`, but the thousand separator is non ASCII for some languages (e.g., French or Swedish, which both uses U+202F). This problem was present except when the size was between 1000 and 1024 bytes because then it would use another code path with a plain `.to_string()`, which was obviously wrong as well.

Just for fun I found where the comment about how «it’s guaranteed to be ASCII» has been introduced: 4c2bf2f2e6231c14a8aa44cb49c828034c342a69. It seems we can’t assume anything we don’t write ourselves is ASCII after all.

Before (0.9.0, `LC_NUMERIC=sv_SE.UTF-8`):
```
$ exa -lb
.rw-r--r--     1 002 ariasuni  6 Apr 15:41 1000_bytes.txt
.rw-r--r-- 1 014Ki ariasuni  6 Apr 15:39 1000_Ki.txt
```

Before (0.10.0):
```
$ exa -lb
.rw-r--r--   1002 ariasuni  6 Apr 15:41 1000_bytes.txt
.rw-r--r-- 1014Ki ariasuni  6 Apr 15:39 1000_Ki.txt
```

After (`LC_NUMERIC=en_US.UTF-8`):
```
$ exa -lb
.rw-r--r--   1 002 ariasuni  6 Apr 15:41 1000_bytes.txt
.rw-r--r-- 1 014Ki ariasuni  6 Apr 15:39 1000_Ki.txt

```

After (`LC_NUMERIC=sv_SE.UTF-8`):
```
$ exa -lb
.rw-r--r--   1 002 ariasuni  6 Apr 15:41 1000_bytes.txt
.rw-r--r-- 1 014Ki ariasuni  6 Apr 15:39 1000_Ki.txt
```

---

Following this:
- Is it voluntary that sizes displayed when the `-B` flag don’t use a thousand separator?
- I’m wondering if `TextCell` shouldn’t have a method that takes a `contents` vec and compute the `DisplayWidth` by itself, instead of relying on every part of the code that needs something more complex than `TextCell::paint()` to do the right thing.

title: Fix completions.zsh syntax
Fix a rounding error in human readable filesizes
body:
Fix #812

For example, for a file of 454 908 bytes, exa displayed 454k but now displays 455k.

This was due to the fact that when the size of the file in the appropriate base (k, M, etc.) was superior to 10, exa stopped displaying the first decimal and formatted the number as an int by casting the float, which in practice was the same thing as if it took the floor of the size. Now, exa uses the same code path that does that the round case, except that it tells the library it uses to use 0 decimals in this particular case.

body:
The absence of the flag was discovered thanks to #816

According to the
https://github.com/ogham/exa/blob/f42957fab8ef1f750315bd957a16baa848177f19/src/options/flags.rs#L65

title: Update determine_time_zone according to GNU manual
body:
Fixes #817 

GNU manual: https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/TZ-Variable.html

> The third format looks like this:

> :characters
If characters begins with a slash, it is an absolute file name; otherwise the library looks for the file /usr/share/zoneinfo/characters.

title: Add options for -n or --numeric-gid-uid.
body:
Closes #807.

This option is only available in -l.
There's test for rendering, but no test for option parsing.
(I don't understand that section of code.)

Also in `ls` this option implies `-l`, is it worth it to follow behavior of `ls`?

title: documentation: add hint how to install exa on Android / Termux
body:
Hi Benjamin,

thank you so much for creating `exa` :pray:

title: Added sudo to installation command for Linux
body:
Don't know about the need for `sudo` for the rest of the operating systems.
Feel free to suggest those as well.

title: Don’t produce extra column sometimes with long grid + header
body:
The number of necessary columns was computed by producing a grid in different sizes and see if all columns were used. However, if there was two files and we tried to fit them in a 3-column grid, it would produces three headers and all three columns would be used; when trying a 4-column grid, the two supplementary headers would fill the third column and the fourth would be empty; so 3 columns would be used.

Now, when the grid fits into the terminal and the number of columns is exactly the number of files to display, it returns immediately instead of trying bigger grids.

Fixes GH-436.

title: Fix Vagrantfile and extended tests
body:
- Remove useless output of rustup install script
- Notify about the installation of `cargo-hack`
- Install `specsheet` for extended tests
- Use a more recent version of just (0.8.0 → 0.8.3)
- Fix “‘exa -lT --icons’ shows icons next to file names in long-tree mode” test

title: Use same styling for spaces between icon and file name
body:
This is only visible when selecting both icon and file name, as most terminal emulators then invert background and foreground color.

It also workaround a Konsole bug: https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=422776

Fix #648

title: feat: add support Typescript and ReasonML projects
body: Close #771

title: feat: add support for SCSS and Stylus Extension
body: Close #769

title: Add Alpine Linux into Installation in Readme
Warm when git feature is disabled instead of ignoring flags
body:
The flags `--git` and `--git-ignore` are caught early during options parsing, so no more checking for git feature is done elsewhere.

Since `--git-ignore` depends on git too [since recently](https://github.com/ogham/exa/pull/653), remove it from help when git feature is disabled.

Extended attributes now don’t artificially depends on git feature being enabled.

Tell if exa was compiled with git support or not when using --help

Tell in the man that some flags needs exa built with git support 

Fix #761

title: feat: New Icons and CLI argument to suppress icons
body:
This PR introduces two improvements:

* a significant number of new icons and includes a comment showing the character to which the extension or file maps to
* A new switch, `--no-icons` to explicitly hide icons, which takes precedence over `--icons`. This switch is useful when using aliases and which to temporarily hide the icons

title: Apply sort order to files in line and grid outputs
body: Fixes #404

title: Add more immediate files
body: Hi, just adding more immediate files let me know if some are not wanted, cheers

title: Add PKGBUILD, *.heic, and *.heif to their respective filetypes
body: This just adds PKGBUILDs as an immediate file, and `*.heic` and `*.heif` and video and photo formats respectively.

title: Add additional TeX compiled files
body:
Specifically .fls and .fdb_latexmk, which the popular [`latexmk`](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/latexmk) tool produces.

There are [more](https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/7770/file-extensions-related-to-latex-etc), but these are particularly common. There are two more that are very common, but I couldn't at first glance see how to add them:

 - `.run.xml` generated by the `biber` bibilography tool
 - `-blx.bib` control file generated by `biblatex`

Might be good to include those too if they're easy to add.

title: Add Nix Icon
add ko to compiled objects
body: Since a Linux/BSD kernel object is an object/compiled file, it should be counted as one along with o, pyc, and the others.

title: Fix icons for symlinked directories
body:
Furthering #516 of grouping sym-linked directories.
This fixes symlinked folders from getting a generic file icon.

title: Fixes #719. Change August to Aug.
body:
Fixes #719 

Month abbreviation for August was incorrect.

title: Update determine_time_zone function to check TZ
body: Instead of defaulting immediately to /etc/filename for the timezone, we can first check whether the TZ environment variable is set. If so, we can pull the corresponding timezone file from /usr/share/zoneinfo. Closes #453.

title: Update File Type Icons
body: Added icon for filetype `.sh`.

title: Add Swift Programming Language icon
Add the documents extension for Apple file formats
body: This adds some extension for document file formats available on Apple's platforms.

title: Add --octal-permissions argument
body:
Using --octal_permissions will insert another column before the existing
permissions where permissions are encoded using octal values as
requested in #316

I tried to stay as close to existing code as possible but as I'm relatively new to Rust I'm open to feedback. 

(closes #316)

title: build: use binary name only
body: This PR may closes #702

title: Add immediate file types for PHP ecosystem
body:
Added the following imemdiate file types for PHP:
- `composer.json` for [Composer](https://getcomposer.org/), the defactor standard package manager for PHP;
- `RoboFile.php`, for [Robo](https://robo.li/), the PHP task runner.

Note: [Phing]() uses `build.xml`, which was already included in the list.

title: git-feature: display if a file is updated but unmerged (conflicted)
Handle timestamps before UNIX_EPOCH (#658)
body:
Instead of returning a Duration since the epoch from file metadata,
which cannot represent times before it, return the SystemTime directly.

Move conversion closer to where it's needed, and perform it infallibly.

---

In contrast to #643, this does not clamp files with pre-epoch times to the epoch:

```
.rw-r--r--    0 freaky  1 Jan  1964 hmm
```

title: Improve default file icon
body: As mentioned in #535…

title: Clean code a bit and fix typos in code documentation
Use git2 instead of parsing .gitignore for --git-ignore
body:
Fix #636 

I can confirm that exa wasn’t able to hide a `node_modules` directory with a `.gitignore` with the line `node_modules/`.

Now, instead of using the [glob](https://crates.io/crates/glob) crate to interpret the lines of `.gitignore`, exa uses part of the code that’s used to display the state of files in a repository.
